results.content: This was a great course and Barath did a great job! I think the course is best for those who need a refresher or who have already had programming experience. The reason I say this is because there is not a lot of explanation as to why certain concepts are important and there are not many self-guided exercises to reinforce concepts. Either way, I learned a lot and I would recommend taking this course.

results.content:
Gently explained, fairly thorough chunks (so far)

need to be able to give micro-feedback (per lecture) too

some quiz questions are not covered in lectures/; for eg decimal type

why are tuples, sets etc un-modifiable? these should be covered in respective lectures

there really are no instructor examples at end of assignments.

The decorator lecture needs to be given a lot more finishing (eg needs to be explained how arguments to inner should match wrapped function etc.) - had to spend a lot of time on other online sources to clear it up.

No assignments after the first few sections, only quizzes? Later sections are what makes Python different and needs hands-on to consolidate concepts.

There is no custom exception lecture yet the assignment for exception handling asks to implement it.

Final comments: please add more assignments at a minimum. Threads and decorators need to be improved by going through all comments/doubts raised by others to get a sense of what's going wrong in delivery. Thanks a lot otherwise, this was great!
results.content_html:
Gently explained, fairly thorough chunks (so far)

need to be able to give micro-feedback (per lecture) too

some quiz questions are not covered in lectures/; for eg decimal type

why are tuples, sets etc un-modifiable? these should be covered in respective lectures

there really are no instructor examples at end of assignments.

The decorator lecture needs to be given a lot more finishing (eg needs to be explained how arguments to inner should match wrapped function etc.) - had to spend a lot of time on other online sources to clear it up.

No assignments after the first few sections, only quizzes? Later sections are what makes Python different and needs hands-on to consolidate concepts.

There is no custom exception lecture yet the assignment for exception handling asks to implement it.

Final comments: please add more assignments at a minimum. Threads and decorators need to be improved by going through all comments/doubts raised by others to get a sense of what's going wrong in delivery. Thanks a lot otherwise, this was great!

results.content: I am first time learner of python and the basics and core python is well demonstrated. Of course, I had prior understanding of C and C++. But the OOPS concepts can be explained better.The implementation in coding is fine but before every section of the OOPS concepts, a little more theoretical explanation of each concept and its importance will be greatly appreciated, especially the abstraction concepts. Even the threading section just dived into the usage in python without explaining what threading is and why we need it. Similarly a few other concepts too. Overall the course is good. Enjoyed it, of course I need more practise to master it, but thanks to this course, I don't fear Python anymore. Great work for a free course. Thank you!!

response.content: You are welcome.will surely address those in the future!

results.content:
Doesn't explain why any of this is useful to know. So either this is very useful and needs to be taught at such a slow pace but the course won't say why or this isn't that useful and the course is just slow.

An example is why do tuples exist at all. When would you ever use a tuple rather than a list? If i had more experience in programming in general i would probably know the answer, but since I'm a beginner it would help a lot to know why you would need to know this. Unless the course is actually aimed at those who already know how all of this is supposed to be used, in which case why bother going at such a slow pace sine all you would really be teaching is python syntax?
results.content_html:

An example is why do tuples exist at all. When would you ever use a tuple rather than a list? If i had more experience in programming in general i would probably know the answer, but since I'm a beginner it would help a lot to know why you would need to know this. Unless the course is actually aimed at those who already know how all of this is supposed to be used, in which case why bother going at such a slow pace sine all you would really be teaching is python syntax?

results.content:
Before Give my review I'd like to give a brief introduction of my Background.
1) I have don't have any programming knowledge neither some Computing degree, I was only familiar with Window and that's all. 
I study Python about 3 months, however the last one I really pushing it.
I had already a bunch  of online courses among Udemy and Youtube plus read few books already.
 Right Now I consider my self on the Intermediate level with Python, or just about it.
I was looking for a course that would go through all the basic already studied as a reinforcement and hence consolidate what I already learnt.  
And this is why I consider this Course a Good 5 Star!

Now I would NOT advice this course for Python Beginners or who has NOT programming language background as I think it may be pretty difficult, this is because he goes quite quick and the initial concept.
So I would no suggest to use this course as your FIRST course, however :

I consider this course in between Beginner/Intermediate spectrum plus at the end give some more advanced topic.
I strongly recommend this course if you already familiar with Basic of Python(or you know already another language) as it moves very quickly to all basic topic in Python plus it gives some very interesting new way to code or writing Style (compared to other beginner course which are more static).

Then I found really interesting from the Object Oriented Programming up as it added my things that i did not know . 

This is my opinion as it served fantastic for my purpose of reinforcing the Basics (and establishing a solid intermediate level) plus adding in each lesson something new. The last 3 topic are quite advanced actually and I will come later to that as well.

 My final advice:

1. If you are really beginner to python and do not know how to program (like I was few months ago) skip this course and come back later(of buy it and watch it when you have some basic)
2. If you are like me that know the basic and need a reinforcement I strongly reccomend you to buy this course.
3. If you are new to Python but know another programming language then for you the same as step 2.

results.content:
So far so good - got it installed where I wanted it . Win 10 install is different than mac , but seems to be working. 
I got atom working on linux ,notepad++ and eclipse on windows,  but I am using eclipse on win 10 for the labs.Just tried TabNine in Atom , but it does not seem to work - probably my fault.  I am really impressed with the power and elegance of python. You are also doing a very good job on explaining concepts - classes was well done . The threading section shows that this language is very well suited to today's multi-core, multi-thread computers. The database section was good - I set up my db on a separate computer and had the additional challenge of allowing remote connections. The only thing I would like to see added to the course is a section on compiling the code , and a section on creating web server apps and using them with Apache and/or IIS.

results.content: The pacing of the course was good. However, on many occasions, the instructions assumed a lot of previous knowledge that a beginner may struggle with. A lot of the SQL statements in the last lecture for instance assumed a large prior knowledge of SQL. The same thing in the Networking section and the Threads section. I think the course may benefit from having a bit more introduction to each Section and including some links to other information explaining the background of the technologies used in the Section. For instance, in the database operations section, include a link to some basic SQL statements so a novice can read that first, familiarize themselves with SQL and then return to this course and see how this is actually being implemented in Python. Overall though, I learned a lot, and I would like to thank the author for taking the time to put this together. Well done!

results.content: It was good at first, but unfortunately the basic concepts aren't explained well. For example, I have only a rough idea of what is a "function", "object", "server","client", etc. and am not always sure how to recognise them. I think the gaps in my knowledge became more apparent and more of a problem in the later stages of the course when I struggled to read the increasingly complex codes - in particular, the introduction of server-client and SQL database inter-communiations during which a lot of details were brushed over. There isn't enough explanation of how the different bits of code might be practically applied. I've realised too that some of the code is non-PEP8-adherent which created some bad habits early on. Also there seem to be a couple of lecture videos missing or in the wrong place. It was frustrating as there were lots of very good aspects of this course too.

results.content: Fantastic course, well paced and in small enough chunks to allow dipping in and out. My only issue is that I took the advice to install Atom (as my laptop would not install Java/Eclipse but found it did not have access to the console for input and argument sessions. I managed to work around the input sessions including the assignments but the argument passing was not possible. I finally cracked it by installing atom-terminal and everything fell into place! I also could not install MySQL/Workbench so installed SQLite and SQLite Studio. I had to amend a few statements to complete the exercises/lectures, but it did work out OK!
results.content_html: Fantastic course, well paced and in small enough chunks to allow dipping in and out. My only issue is that I took the advice to install Atom (as my laptop would not install Java/Eclipse but found it did not have access to the console for input and argument sessions. I managed to work around the input sessions including the assignments but the argument passing was not possible. I finally cracked it by installing atom-terminal and everything fell into place! I also could not install MySQL/Workbench so installed SQLite and SQLite Studio. I had to amend a few statements to complete the exercises/lectures, but it did work out OK!

results.content: I have a good knowledge of Python already - hoping to extend this to some more advanced topics. I found the networking section very good in particular - a complex area well developed a step at a time. I have used OOP for Python before, but abstraction and interfaces were new to me. I also learned some new aspects of lambdas and decorators. All in all a very good course with an unusually broad coverage for an introductory course.
results.content_html: I have a good knowledge of Python already - hoping to extend this to some more advanced topics. I found the networking section very good in particular - a complex area well developed a step at a time. I have used OOP for Python before, but abstraction and interfaces were new to me. I also learned some new aspects of lambdas and decorators. All in all a very good course with an unusually broad coverage for an introductory course.

results.content:
Dieser Kurs behandelt alle wichtigen Aspekte von Python in kompakter aber verständlicher Form. Die Beispiele werden sofort in der Entwicklungsumgebung, PyDev unter Eclipse, verifiziert und vertiefen somit das Gelernte. Quizze am Ende der Lektionen eröffnen Wissenslücken und animieren zur Wiederholung der entsprechenden Lektion. 

This course covers all important aspects of Python in a compact but understandable way. The examples are immediately verified in the development environment, PyDev under Eclipse, and deepen what was learned. Quizzes at the end of the lesson open up gaps in knowledge and encourage people to repeat the lesson.

results.content:
Straightforward and so far well explained.
On some of the more complex concepts it might be helpful to spend a bit more time on the discussion.  For example, on decorator functions, we are told to use nested functions (e.g. def inner(n) ) but not why it is needed or how variables and control flow through the logic.
Also, it would be helpful to identify where we could obtain more information on resources available.
results.content_html:
Straightforward and so far well explained.
On some of the more complex concepts it might be helpful to spend a bit more time on the discussion. For example, on decorator functions, we are told to use nested functions (e.g. def inner(n) ) but not why it is needed or how variables and control flow through the logic.

results.content:
This course is great for beginners and for people with some programming knowledge who wish to learn Python. Beginners will have difficult about half way through the course as there are some difficult concepts but don't worry if you don't fully understand them at first, exposure is good and if you need to use it later you can use google or some other learning material to supplement your learning. 

The instructor is good at explaining his code and what everything means. His English is also very good, everything was clear, sometimes at the beginning of videos there is a static noise but that's quite minor. Overall I enjoyed this course and the assignments but I wish the quizzes were a bit longer and challenging, I think they are way too simple.

There is a bit difficulty in all the installations mentioned in the course. You have to search a lot on google for setup help especially if you are working on Windows, that is time consuming. Rest this course is great to start learning Python free.

results.content: First Lessons are PERFECT.  Good job! I loved the course!  In about two hours you will be able to code simple thngs, loops , conditional and Pythons Overall logic. Excellent for starters. However, we reach a point where the difficulty slope gets too steep and professor is waaaay too fast. A lot of information with very little examples. A lot of things are just mentioned once, speciallly arround the object orient programming, for a newcommer  I reached a point where I was extremely confused because it was assumed that I understood in just one lesson. Nonetheless for a future, I consider this short video format is perfect to come back and refresh once you got more experience in Python.

results.content:
First of all, Bharath, thank you for a such great intro to the Python! Well, the course gives a REALLY good glimpse about the language. Keep moving it to even better success! 

Obviously both "basic" and "advanced" parts have plenty of room for improvement: what is inside a class? how imports work? some jedi technics with the lambdas? multiple inheritance? Python's method resolution order ... a deeper explanation of the threads synchronization primitives, GUI, math, add more real life examples, etc., etc., etc. 

But! Still, again, it gives a REALLY good glimpse about the language, and I would recommend this course to anyone who is absolutely beginner in the Python.

Thank you!
results.content_html:
First of all, Bharath, thank you for a such great intro to the Python! Well, the course gives a REALLY good glimpse about the language. Keep moving it to even better success!

Obviously both "basic" and "advanced" parts have plenty of room for improvement: what is inside a class? how imports work? some jedi technics with the lambdas? multiple inheritance? Python's method resolution order ... a deeper explanation of the threads synchronization primitives, GUI, math, add more real life examples, etc., etc., etc.

But! Still, again, it gives a REALLY good glimpse about the language, and I would recommend this course to anyone who is absolutely beginner in the Python.

Thank you!

results.content: An excellent start into the Python language. There is a lot of stuff it doesn't cover (of course) but the basics are covered pretty well. This course did the contrary, I managed to understand every single detail of the basics of python and I will come back every time i need to review the basics. That's why I found this course to be great for me, especially because Python is not my first language. I now have a solid grasp of Python basics. The quick knowledge checks and assignments really helped me to understand Python better than if I would just copy the instructor for an entire course. Otherwise, a bit more explanation and a slightly slower paced course might be more effective for you.

results.content:
Sometimes exercice repeats exactly the content. Also, the section order is quite strange. E.g. the example  where a function parameter (in section 7) comes before functions are described (section 10).
Often too basic exercises. They are really too close to the lesson and does not help to actually imagine "real life" / advanced usage. I guess that having a common thread between exercices would help.
Also, it lacks something about virtualenv which seems to be an important python feature to use. For this reason, the note is between Middle and Good.
results.content_html:
Sometimes exercice repeats exactly the content. Also, the section order is quite strange. E.g. the example where a function parameter (in section 7) comes before functions are described (section 10).
Often too basic exercises. They are really too close to the lesson and does not help to actually imagine "real life" / advanced usage. I guess that having a common thread between exercices would help.
Also, it lacks something about virtualenv which seems to be an important python feature to use. For this reason, the note is between Middle and Good.
